description.narrative: 29244 Strengthening Legal and Policy Environments for increased access to HIV/SRH services and access to justice.

activity-description.narrative: Advocate for inclusive policy and programmes targeting Key Populations and law reform
Advocate for inclusive policy and programmes targeting Key Populations and law reform
Advocate for inclusive policy and programmes targeting Key Populations and law reform

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative: OUTPUT 1: National Legal Environment Assessments and National Action Plans completed - 5 National Steering Committees Established - 5 Legal & Policy Environment Assessments finalized and action plan developed and validated OUTPUT 2: Law, Policy and Strategy review as per recommendations of LEA and as prioritized in National Action Plan - 5 Political Scans finalized; - Number of National law, policy, strategy reviews carried out in 5 countries OUTPUT 3: Capacity strengthening for parliamentarians, policy makers, law enforcement and the judiciary on HIV/SRH - 4 Regional capacity strengthening meetings conducted; - Number of activities implemented by countries post training OUTPUT 4: Relevant tools and guidance on HIV/SRH needs and rights of each YKPs developed. - 4 Tools developed and disseminated OUTPUT 5:Assist SADC to strengthen regional frameworks to ensure inclusion of HIV/SRH needs/rights of YKPs - 5x6 young key populations travel to regional framework meetings every year - SADC supported to include young key populations in regional frameworks OUTPUT 6: Capacity strengthening for young People on HIV/SRH rights and access to justice - 5x4 National meetings conducted for young key populations; Small grants for young key population advocacy made in each country: - Annual regional meetings for YKPs OUTPUT 7: Mechanism for community inputs into policy and service provision established - 2 Regional consultations for Young Key Populations held ; - Advocacy Working Group established for Young Key Populations in each country OUTPUT 8: Baseline study and mid-term review - 5 baseline studies implemented, reported and disseminated ; - Development of appropriate indicators and project milestones; - Project mid-term review carried out, reported and disseminated OUTPUT 9 Operational research on barriers to SRHR for young key populations,service needs and gaps - Five country research agendas formulated and research proposals for country studies develope

comment.narrative: 0 National Steering Committee 1 Draft Legal Environment Assessment Report - Zimbabwe 0 Engagement Scans in the five countries 0 National Action Plans 1 Draft SADC HIV/TB/SRH Strategy 1 Draft Advocacy Guide for MSM 1 Draft SRH Score Card

1. Five National Action Plans Developed 2. Legal Environment Assessment Launched in the five countries. 3. Calendar of Law and Policy reform developed 4. Capacity Development of YKP Groups and CSO on engaging in law and policy reform undertaken 5. Online platform for monitoring CSO Advocacy initiatives developed 6. Capacity building of National Steering Committees on Human Rights, HIV/SRH and the Law; Integration of HIV/HR/ SRH in the law enforcement curriculum undertaken. 7. Roll out YKP Score card and Develop KP Stigma Index Guideline 8. Strengthen advocacy capacity activities for young SW and LGBTI, young people in prison and persons who use drugs on human rights and access to justice. 9. Implement Small grants in the five countries. 10. YKPs capacity on global and regional commitments strengthened 11. SADC capacity to lead and coordinate implementation of the KP strategy enhanced. 12. Fieldwork for Angola Baseline undertaken 13. Midterm Review for the LPP project conducted 14. YKP Indicator framework finalized 15. Operational Research findings presented, and country specific publications and research briefs produced. 16. Cross country comparative analysis of change process undertaken.

INTERVENTION AREA 1: National Legal Environment Assessments and National Action Plans Conducted In 5 Countries
Finalization of the LEA Reports. Key populations and vulnerable groups continue to be marginalized, discriminated and stigmatized when it comes to access to sexual reproductive health and HIV services evident by the increase in new infections in this group across the sub Saharan Africa. Over the past 24 months, the Linking policy to programme project has provided technical support for the finalization and publication of the Legal Environment Assessments (LEA) Reports. 2019 focused on the review of the LEA reports from Angola, Madagascar, Zambia and Zimbabwe resulting in three of the reports being published at national level by the National AIDS Commission and UNDP Country Office websites as well as the Global Commission on HIV and the Law (GCHL) website. Zimbabwe officially launched its LEA Report on the 30th November in Masvingo as part of the World AIDS Day (WAD) commemoration. An occasion graced by the Honorable Minister of Health and attended by over 200 delegates. The launch held on the eve of the WAD under the theme “Communities make a difference” was fitting for the recognition of Key populations and other vulnerable groups active in the prevention of new HIV infection and human rights protection. Angola launched its LEA Report and National Action plan after being adopted by the NAC, CSO, Ombudsman and Ministry of Health, however opted for the translation of the Portuguese LEA report into English prior to being published. Both versions of the report will be published in the first quarter of 2020. To increase access to information and popularize some of the findings of the LEA. Angola developed policy briefs in four critical areas of the report, criminalisation of HIV and its implications, Women - gender equality, Key populations and Access to justice. These formed the basis for engagement with stakeholder. Angola is in the process of reviewing its HIV law and proposals seek to increase the penalty for intentional transmission of HIV which contravenes international law and practice. The LEA report for Mozambique has been completed and currently awaiting clearance from the National AIDS Commission. The reports can be accessed from the following websites below; Zimbabwe: www.zw.undp.org; http://www.zw.undp.org/content/zimbabwe/en/home/publications/zimbabwe--legal-environment-assesment-for-hiv--tb--sexual-and-re0.html Zambia: www.http://zm.undp.orghttp://www.zm.undp.org/content/zambia/en/home/library/poverty/zambia-legal-environment-assessment-for-hiv--tb-and-sexual-and-r.html Global Commission on HIV and Law website - https://hivlawcommission.org/
There have been several activities undertaken by project countries post the finalization of the LEA Reports. A series of consultation meetings, workshops with various groups, civil society organisations and communities were organized to disseminate the findings and recommendations the LEA in Angola, Zambia and Zimbabwe. Such meetings provided a platform to discuss the recommendations in depth, identify strategies for possible implementation of the recommendation, most critical was the sensitization of citizens on the structural barriers to accessing SRH/HIV services, implication of criminalisation of HIV and key populations, the challenges related to poor legislation and policies that are exclusive of other members of society and hinder access to services. Madagascar, Mozambique and Angola are the three project countries that have decriminalized adult consensual same sex relationships (Madagascar does not have any legislation). This provides an opportunity for re-engagement on inclusive policy and legal reform for Y/KPs including transformation of the way information, education and counselling (IEC) materials are developed for the prevention of new HIV infections. b. The Engagement Scan The Civil Society Engagement Scan (ES) in Health policy and the law has been published and operationalized in the five countries. The ES is aimed at strengthening civil society organisations and young key populations with the relevant policy and legal advocacy skills and knowledge on International, Regional instruments that could be used to hold States accountable for human rights violations. The ES further provides information on strategies and guidance for engaging national Institutions such as the human Rights commissions, Gender Commissions available to key population for the advancement of or protection of citizens against violations or upholding the principles human rights. A training programme has been established on the ES to operationalize the tool, core-delivered with AMSHER. The training provides practical experiences on how to prepare various reports i.e. shadow reports, strategic letters to national, regional and international institutions, identifying human rights violation and strategies for recourse, monitoring states for compliance to UN human rights conventions. By the end of the training participants can apply the engagement scan tool and possibly empower other young people on its use. c. Implementation of the National Action Plans. The completion of the LEA report is followed by the development of a national action plan a process led by the National Steering Committee (NSC). The national action plan identifies priorities and proposes actions required for the implementation of the LEA recommendations. The national action plans can either be a standalone document or can be integrated into an existing national document i.e. National AIDS Commission (NAC) National Monitoring Plan. In Zimbabwe and Angola, the LEA recommendations have been integrated in the National Key Populations Implementation Plan. In Zimbabwe the KP plan was launched together with the LEA in November 2019 as part of the activities culminating to the World AIDS Day. The integration of the LEA recommendation in national strategic frameworks is the most sustainable approach to ensuring its implementation, resource allocation and monitoring of outcomes. The implementation of the national action plans takes various forms at national level, dependent on the national advocacy requirements for initiating policy or legal reform processes. In Angola, the country office has contributed towards the development of the National HIV/AIDS Strategic Plan (NSP) 2019 – 2022 which has been informed by the LEA. The LEA recommendations have been contextualized under the strategic objective that aims to promote Zero Discrimination thematic area. The NSP was adopted by the National AIDS Commission in December 2019. Further a National Strategy on the Prevention of Mother to Child Transmission of HIV (PMTCT) which include some of the recommendations from the LEA has been developed in collaboration with other UN agencies. The PMTCT Strategy is yet to be approved by the Ministry of Health. The country office has been actively engaged in high level meetings with the Ministry of Health, HIV Law Commission and the Presidency on decriminalization of HIV. A joint UNAIDS/UNDP position statement on new Penal Code provisions was tabled to the Speaker of Parliament. Angola civil society organisations were also sensitised on the need to intensify advocacy for decriminalization of HIV. In Madagascar the NSP is up for midterm review in 2020. Its envisaged that the recommendations of the LEA will be incorporated into the NSP following the review. Mozambique is also working towards the development of a Key Population Implementation Plan and the country is part of the Global Partnership on HIV Stigma and discrimination in Africa which will partly be informed by the LEA findings.
INTERVENTION AREA 2: Law, Policy and Strategy review undertaken in 5 countries
a. Integration of YKP/KPs into National Strategies and Policies Post the LEA the country offices engaged in several activities aimed at advocacy for specific recommendation outlined in the LEA report. Policy and law reform in the different countries are led by Ministries, departments and specific commissions established for law reform. Most countries are not transparent with the reform processes, often announced when the law is tabled in Parliament or draft policy developed. The LEAs have identified several legislation and policies that need improvement however the pace of reform and prioritization of these legislations and policies by governments is beyond the remit of this project. Countries with HIV laws under review or in the pipeline are Angola and Madagascar, the UNDP CO working with the NACs are already involved in the processes and Young key populations have been sensitized to be actively engaged in the discussions. In Mozambique YKPs, Law makers and Law Enforcement agents (Ministry of Justice, Police, National Prosecutors, Supreme Court Officials) Human Rights Commission, Ombudsman Office, were sensitised on the HIV and AIDS National Strategic Plan 2015 – 2020. This was aimed at increasing participants knowledge on the rights of Key Populations and vulnerable groups and how legal and policy barriers impact key population’s access to sexual reproductive health and HIV services and other harm reduction related programmes. The process for the fifth NSP development (2021+) has been initiated. UNDP is expected to play a significant role in advocating for the inclusion of the legal issue’s highlighted in the LEA recommendations in the new NSP. The Law n.19/2014 which seeks to protect People living with HIV, KPs, employees and Job seekers against stigma and discrimination was also disseminated. Technical advisor was secured to facilitate the review of Family Law n.10/2004 and Succession Bill to be aligned to International and regional treaties. The law is to clearly state the right to form a union and adopt children by same sex couples including inheritance. This law is yet to be tabled in Parliament. UNDP CO collaborating with the PWID/PWUD CSOs advocated for the review of the Drug Law n. º 3/97. Mozambique is one of the drug corridor countries with increasing rates of users. Discussions are ongoing with the government (Police, Ministry of Justice and CSOs) for the establishment of responsive harm reduction programmes. A national dialogue on the decriminalization of drug use was undertaken. The dialogue revealed that the country is at different levels of readiness regards progressive law reform that decriminalizes drug use. The meeting concluded that harm reduction programmes should be strengthened, and a Harm Reduction Action Plan developed with full participation of all stakeholders. Advocacy for the elimination of early child marriage by CSOs working on women and children’s issues, Parliament and Commission of Social Affairs resulted on the review and adoption of the law (Law to Prevent and Combat Early Marriage) by Parliament. The law has increased the marriage age for all to 18 years. Sensitization of communities, traditional authorities and all related stakeholders on the law and penalties therein is yet to follow. b. Support capacity development of YKP groups and CSO on engaging in Law and policy reform. Several capacity building interventions were delivered at national and regional level to strengthen CSO capacities on strategic engagement with the Government and Parliamentarians or law makers using the LEA outcomes and the Engagement scan which provides the various opportunities for advocacy. In Mozambique Key Populations CSOs were introduced to the Guidelines (Framework) for Key Population Assistance in Medical Units. Participants included CSO’s of key populations (MSM, CSW, IDIU, Prisons) and CSO’s of adolescents and young women. The meeting was aimed at strengthening advocacy skills for KPs and knowledge on government’s commitments towards the improvement of KP targeted interventions. As part of creating awareness of the UN staff on the rights of Key Populations, Zimbabwe had its first sensitization meeting for UNDP, the Global fund Program Management Unit, UN Staff Zimbabwe and National Aids Commission. The meeting attended by 46 members of staff was led by the CSOs including GALZ, TIRZ, WAAD and TRANSMART. The meeting aimed at providing a platform to UNDP GF PMU staff to understand sensitive matters concerning KPs during provision of support services to KPs; provide a platform to KPs to share their experiences when seeking services from UNDP GF PMU staff and other support staff. The approach to the delivery of the training was participatory using (stereotyping, boxes and binaries, gallery walk, visionary exercises, plenary discussions and informative games. This allowed participants to internalize the issues and experiences of KPs and learn to be more sensitive and responsive to their needs especially when looking for support from the CO; the meeting outcome resulted in participants being less prejudiced and willing to reconcile their sexuality and religious beliefs; showing self-discovery or renewed; demystified myths and misconceptions about sexual orientation and gender identity and human sexuality. Positive lessons from this workshop is the recognition for similar sensitization sessions for the wider UNDP staff and other UN Agencies and the sharing of relevant IEC materials that can be used to enhance knowledge of UNDP personnel further; the need to sensitise middle and senior management separately was also recommended to promote a supportive and enabling work environment for LGBTI persons in the office. In Zimbabwe KPs were also sensitised on the National AIDS Commission HIV/AIDS National Strategy to end AIDS by 2030, Global Fund programme activities and priorities including identifying strategies for meaningfully participating in the planning and implementation of programmes led by the UN, this was to encourage more ownership of the KP Agenda within the GF. This meeting also served as an opportunity to break stigma and discrimination related barriers between the institutions and CSOs. In Angola, UNDP collaborating with UNAIDS and ANASO engaged on several intervention at Provincial Level (Kwanza Norte) aimed at creating awareness on the current situation regarding criminalization of HIV and the new criminal code (HIV Act) which has stiffer penalties on HIV transmission, its impact and the alternatives of including willful transmission in criminal Law and not the HIV Act. Created more awareness on the constitutional fundamental rights, particularly right to health, privacy, education and information and access to justice. Continued advocacy for the integration of the SADC Strategy on HIV Prevention treatment and care and SRH Rights for KPs, adoption of the SADC HIV model law. These interventions will be scaled up across the country. Angola, Zambia and Zimbabwe have strengthened partnerships with the National Human Rights Institutions for the increased protection of human rights for KPs. At regional level UNDP collaborating with AMSHER facilitated a Regional Training of YKPs from the project countries on the operationalization of the Engagement Scan. The training attended by 25 YKs was held in September in Pretoria South Africa. The overall objective of the regional meeting was to create a pool of international and regional YKP SOGIR advocates who can spear head advocacy for the inclusion of the YKPs issues in the policy and national programmes for young people in general. YKPs were capacitated on the application of the Engagement Scan (ES) and introduced to the different strategies for engaging in advocacy for policy reform. The meeting reviewed the current level of engagement of YKPs in policy advocacy and identified strengths and challenges; strengthened the capacity of YKPs to understand and apply the ES tool frameworks or systems of protection of SRHR both at national and regional levels; strengthened capacity of YKPs to claim their rights and effectively engage in legal and policy reform processes; developed strategies for adaptation of the tool to YKP advocacy in each country; and developed a plan for wider dissemination to and utilisation of the tool by YKPs. By the end of the meeting YKPs capacities were enhanced on existing national human rights mechanisms that have explicit functions of protecting citizens, and identified the various entry points for policy engagement; YKPs were able to identify policy and legal gaps, develop draft letters to policy makers, strategic institutions (Ministries, National Human rights Institutions) requesting for redress; identified issues for presentation to International forums. The training methodology adopted is very practical, engaging and inclusive. The participants were drawn from the different KP communities and included MSM, TG, SW, PWUD and were all below the age of 24. Age was a major criterion when selecting the beneficiaries to participate in the meeting. Plans were developed for the roll out of the ES and specific issues were identified, envisaged that these would be supported in 2020. A follow up national training on the engagement scan was also undertaken in Madagascar, with a total of 26 participants from different regions. This was aimed at creating more awareness on the engagement scan as a tool for advocacy amongst young people. In October, UNDP Zambia through UBRAF resources collaborated with AMSHeR to support a workshop for young people on engagement scan with a focus on the right to health as an enabler to reduce the various HIV risks and promote uptake of SRH services; empower YKPs on strategies for claiming their rights; and introduce them to UNDOC programme activities. The meeting also provided an opportunity to disseminate the LEA recommendations. c. Set up an online platform to facilitate and monitor advocacy activities by KP groups and CSOs. The MTR has recognised the challenges related to the development of an online platform. This activity assumed that KP CSOs that are a part of the project have high level organisational systems capability that would easily integrate the online system. It further assumed that costs related to access to internet and equipment would be provided without any additional costs by the CSO i.e. increase of bandwidth to allow flow of information. For a successful interactive online platform, it would require a dedicated person to continuously update, scan the environment, monitor, edit and occasionally disseminate information to participating CSOs. Most partners have minimum staff complement implementing various projects. The target of the project is “young key populations” whom are mostly freelancers to the KP organisations and do not have permanent base to implement the online platform further compromised the establishment of this component of the activities. In consultation with young people, whatsupp was the preferred medium for sharing information across themselves and email group for sharing documents. YKPs also mentioned the limitations to access to personal internet for such an intervention. In view of the above the development of an online platform was then suspended. The other challenge relates to the developing of a calendar of law and policy reform processes. It was observed that Ministries and policy makers have their own, processes and procedures for the law and policy reform. The dates are often not known nor publicized which makes it a challenge for CSO to be proactive with engaging in these processes.
INTERVENTION AREA 3: Capacity Strengthening Activities for Parliamentarians, Policy makers, Law Enforcement and the Judiciary undertaken in Five countries (UNDP).
a. Strengthening capacities of Members of Parliament on the rights of Key Populations and young people. The inclusion of Parliamentarians in the LEA processes, AWG and NSC, created an enabling environment for engagement with law makers on discriminatory, punitive and coercive laws that are a barrier to access to justice and human rights including healthcare services for young key populations. Zimbabwe and Zambia are the only two project countries that criminalize sexual orientation (LGBTI Community). To create awareness on the Constitutional provisions, the right to equal protection & equality before the law, access to justice, international and reginal protocols ratified by the country, Parliamentarians were capacitated on the right of key populations within the law. In Zimbabwe, UNDP in partnership with UNAIDS, NAC and KP CSO collaborated with Parliament specifically the Portfolio Committee on Health and Child Care & the Thematic Committee on HIV and AIDS to discuss the country’s performance against the global commitments such as 90-90-90 targets by 2020 and ending AIDS as public health threat by 2030. This also provided a platform for dissemination of the LEA findings and recommendations, reach consensus on priorities that could be driven by Parliamentarians. Members of Parliament are crucial for the development of enabling legislative environment and progressive legal reform processes that are inclusive of key populations. Parliamentarians are also a strategic partner in advocating for policies that prevent discrimination, intolerance and human rights violations. Members of Parliament are well positioned to mobilize action by influencing government, social, religious and traditional leaders and public officials to take positive action and strengthen accountability. A three-day meeting held in Bulawayo in March 2019 with Parliamentarians focused on identifying key issues and challenges faced by adolescent girls and young women (AGYW) and key populations especially sex workers and the broader LGBTI community. The meeting provided an opportunity for the KPs to clearly articulate their issues and challenges related to unfavorable legal and policies frameworks. The meeting resulted on the following: • the need to advocate for scaled up services for sex workers including health clinic and drop - in centers in both urban and rural areas. • begin a process for policy and legal review with the aim of de-criminalizing sex work and ensuring a conducive environment for KPs in general. • move a motion (in Parliament) for government to provide free sanitary wear for girls in schools and out of schools (a key issue raised by young girls). • revisit age restrictions on access to SRHR and HIV services and related policies to allow free and non-discriminatory access by adolescents and young people. • review Health and HIV Acts with a view of safeguarding access to non-discriminatory services; health for all including the issue of discrimination in health care settings, particularly for key populations. • initiate dialogue among the Parliamentary Committees on LGBTI rights a meeting to be led by the community and UN agencies. It was evident that most of the Parliamentarians were interacting with the LGBTI community for the first time resulting in MPs requesting for more dialogues and exposure to KP issues for better understanding of the issues. Additionally, UNDP in collaboration with other UN agencies using UBRAF resources, a field tour was organized for Parliamentarians aimed at facilitating an interactive session with Key populations. The interface with the KP community helped the MPs to understand the underlying structural determinants of the epidemic among prison inmates, young people, sex workers and the LGBTI Community. It also helped them understand community realities and experiences, challenges and limitations in accessing SRH/HIV services and the drivers for new infections, among the community. The MPs interfaced with prison inmates, female and male sex workers, MSM, Transgender, Intersex, Gays and Lesbians. The Parliamentarians were drawn from the Portfolio Committee on Health and Child Care; Thematic Committee on HIV and AIDS; Portfolio committee on Justice and Portfolio Committee on Gender. In Madagascar partnership was established with the National Assembly Deputy President of the Health Portfolio Committee and Senator. A half day meeting was held for policy makers including Parliamentarians, Parliamentary Assistance, SE/CNLS, Ministry of Health, HIV National programme, YKPs, Directors from the Ministry of Youth and the Ministry of Justice and the Representative of the National HIV and Law Commission. The aim was to sensitise Parliamentarians on the LEA findings, broker partnerships and develop a strategy for engaging with some of the relevant portfolio committees. The first meeting is scheduled for the first quarter of 2020. In 2017 UNDP collaborating with UNFPA supported SADC Parliamentary Forum with the Development of Minimum Standards for the Protection of the Sexual and Reproductive Health of Key Populations in the SADC Region. The Minimum Standards published in 2018 define essential requirements and opportunities for improving protections for Key Populations against stigma, discrimination and violence; addressing the negative effects of punitive laws, policies and cultural practices; including ensuring access to relevant information and services for HIV prevention and health promotion. The Standards give due regard to the range of country contexts that exist across SADC for improving protections for Key Populations while, at the same time, clarify essential obligations of all Member States for the protection and promotion of health and human rights for all. Furthermore, they indicate the clear opportunities to advance the SRHR of Key Populations through Parliaments by the legislative, budgetary, oversight and representative functions of SADC MPs. In 2019 the LPP Project together with UNFPA and SADC PF sponsored a satellite session at the International Conference on AIDS in Sub Saharan Africa (ICASA) on the 5th December. Participating in the session were Members of Parliament. The conference themed “Parliamentarians protecting the Sexual and Reproductive Health Rights for Key Populations: The case of the SADC Parliamentary Forum” was also attended by a YKP as a panelist. The objectives of the session was to promote the SADC PF Minimum Standards for the protection of SRH to the African continent and galvanize Parliaments to promote an enabling environment for protection of SRH for key populations; highlight the barriers to accessing SRH services by Key Populations; share concrete actions that national parliaments can do to protect the SRH for Key Populations and lastly promote partnership of national parliaments with civil society organizations to strengthen domestication and enforcement/application of the SADC Minimum Standards.
b. Conduct Regional training on the development of national curricula on the role of Law enforcement in protecting the rights of KP groups.
The Law Enforcement regional meeting was held in March 2019 in Johannesburg with a total of 39 law enforcement Officers from eight countries namely Angola, Eswatini, Lesotho, Madagascar, Mozambique, Namibia, Zambia and Zimbabwe including South African based regional CSO SWEAT& AMSHeR, Nairobi- KELIN and UNODC. The overall objective of the meeting was to discuss strategies for integrating key population issues in national curricula of law enforcement officers in a sustained manner with the view of protecting the rights of key populations, including young key populations; reducing stigma, discrimination and human rights violations; promoting equitable access to HIV and sexual and reproductive health care services, and promoting access to justice. The overall objective was to conduct a regional, consultative and exploratory meeting with law enforcement training institutions and other key stakeholders from the five project countries. Specific objectives included i. establish how human rights and access to sexual reproductive health and rights and access to justice have taken place in their respective countries and/or been integrated into the national training curriculum for law enforcement officers; ii. share best practices on the training of law enforcement officers on human rights, increased access to justice, policing and respect of the rights of key populations, women and children; iii. discuss strategies and actions for integrating HIV, SRHR, human rights and key populations into law enforcement training and (iv) set up a Steering Committee to carry the work forward. iv. Consolidate findings from the regional meeting and produce a paper on strategies and actions for integrating human rights, SRHR and key populations issues in law enforcement training. v. Produce a strategic guide and work plan to initiate pilot activities for integrating human rights, SRHR, HIV and key population issues in the training curricula of law enforcement officials in Angola, Madagascar, Mozambique, Zambia and Zimbabwe. The meeting established that there are several ongoing initiatives in the different countries that are aimed at the prevention of HIV/AIDS infections within the police force either internally or externally. The countries are also at different levels of implementation of different activities related to capacity building; research, assessments, awareness raising campaigns; service provision such as ART support, HIV testing and counselling. Entry points used for establishing HIV programmes include the country national strategic plan on HIV/AIDS, legislation, National Policies for HIV as well as sector policies. The training of police officers on HIV/TB/SRH is either integrated in the national curriculum for police training or in-service training. However, training is focused on the basic facts around HIV and prevention and not from the human rights perspective. Several training manuals have been developed by countries, however the content of training varies indicating the need to have a harmonized comprehensive master training manual for police training institutes that includes the rights of key populations and further based on the rights-based approach. UNODC has also developed a training manual for law enforcement officers which should serve as basis for the curriculum review for countries. The broad topics covered in the training of law enforcement officers include Socialization, Human rights, SRH rights gender equality, HIV/AIDS/TB/STI, stigma and discrimination, child protection, gender-based violence, NCDs, international and regional conventions and protocol. All countries adopted the proposal for developing a comprehensive curriculum for law enforcement; establish of a virtual committee with country representatives for sharing of experiences and updates; securing an external consultant to assist countries with manual development; the meeting recognized that manual integration will move at a different pace and timeframes for completion. Zimbabwe indicated that the environment for such an initiative is not favorable and therefore would focus on advocacy with Senior Commissioners.
c. Support the process of integrating KP in the national curricula of Law Enforcement Training Institutions
Subsequent to the Regional meeting for Law Enforcement (LE) held in March 2019, two Regional consultants were secured to provide overall coordination of the countries and substantive contribution towards the curriculum development. Several national consultations have been held in Zambia and Madagascar with Senior Commissioners with a view of getting consensus and approval for the development of an integrated comprehensive curriculum for law enforcement officers training inclusive of key populations related issues. In Madagascar, drawing from the National Strategic Plan 2018-2022 which commits to strengthening multisector response. UNDP collaborated with OHCHR in strengthening capacities of Law enforcement Officers on issues affecting key populations and existing laws that are protective to key populations especially sex workers. A series of sensitization meetings were held with a total coverage of 90 law enforcement officers sensitised on HIV and key populations rights. The meeting provided a platform for the dissemination of the HIV national strategy and the LEA recommendations; agree on strategies for effective coordination of the national response interventions; improve knowledge on the HIV/STI/TB Prevention and the rights of key populations and HIV; target out of school youth who are the most vulnerable population to new infection; increase HIV testing and counselling including care to reach the 90-90-90 targets; increase prevention of mother-to-child transmission of HIV. The Ministry of Public Security committed to the implementation of the components of the NSP that relates to security forces; continue with the dissemination of the LEA findings and sensitization of Police on KP issues. The ministry was further presented with a computer to strengthen its monitoring system. In Zambia a round table advocacy meeting aimed at promoting a right’s based national response to HIV and health services within the security forces was held in the Copperbelt province. The meeting provided a platform to discuss with Senior Commissioners and reach consensus on the regional commitments on strengthening curriculum development and sustainability in HIV/STI/TB training within Institutes, and further disseminate the LEA findings and recommendations. These discussions were led by the Zambia Police HIV Secretariat responsible for training on HIV/TB, self-testing and PreP. The meeting further introduced discussions on the rights of key populations and state obligation towards the protection of key populations especially LGBTI community within police custody. Several advocacy meetings were subsequently held with various Police stakeholders to solicit buy in for the curriculum development. Follow up meetings will need to agree on manual priorities and adaptation of other manuals to address current gaps, and identification of authors. Technical support would be required for the second phase of drafting. Zambia is promoting itself as a Christian country and discriminatory (homophobic) statements have been made at the highest political level. Arbitrary arrests, unlawful detentions, exhortations, humiliations, unlawful examinations and general discrimination has been experienced by key populations especially MSM community. Zimbabwe political environment is presently hostile and unfavorable, therefore engagement with Senior Police leadership on the review and update of the curriculum to have a holistic approach to HIV and KP programming has been slow. Post the regional meeting a roadmap was developed by the NAC and UNDP on the strategy for integrating human rights, SRHR and HIV issues of key populations in national curricular, however implementation of the roadmap have been futile with the Law Enforcement seniors leadership refusing to engage or participate in any organized meetings.
d. Strengthening Capacity of the Zambia Medical Association for Effective Management of Intersex Community.
Post the completion of the LEA partnership was established with the Zambian Medical Association for the development of an Intersex Management Protocol. UNDP in collaboration with the Intersex community has facilitated meetings with the Medical Association and this initiative is led by one of the doctors involved in providing affirming surgery to the intersex community. A concept note for the development of an Intersex Management protocol has been developed which should guide the development of the protocol. Partnership have been established with UNDP Bangkok to facilitate south-south cooperation in capacity building and sharing of experiences. The medical Association is yet to develop terms of reference for this assignment.
e. Strengthening National Commissions and other Government Officials capacities for the Protection of Key Populations.
To further the advocacy agenda on law and policy reform, strategic partnerships were established with national institutions for the increased protection of key populations and access to justice. Zambia country office collaborating with TransBantu organized a round table discussion with members of the National Human Rights Commission (NHRC) to discuss the human rights violations against persons with different sexual orientation and broader key populations. This happens in the wake of two adult MSM Zambians nationals imprisoned for being in a consensual relationship. The KPs presented the challenges and human rights violations experienced at the hands of law enforcements officers and further discussed the role of the NHRC in protecting citizens including KPs. It transpired that Commissioners were not aware of these violations as none were officially reported to the Institution. Several issues were raised related to the lack of reporting including fear, discrimination, the lack of knowledge on the existence of reporting mechanisms by KPs etc. This culminated to a two-day national dialogue organized by the Key Populations CSOs collaborating with the NHRC Commissioners and including young key populations in November. The national dialogue themed “Leaving no one behind: broadening understanding of gender and sharing experience of transgender and intersex persons in Zambia” focused on creating an enabling and safe environment for the communities; discuss legal and policy barriers in accessing services i.e. SRH, national Identity, stigma and discrimination to mention a few. The outcome of this meeting was the commitment towards the establishment of an informal desk and identification of a focal point to monitor Y/KP complaints within the NHRC and champions or friends of KPs also identified within the police station. In Zimbabwe UNDP facilitated a Gender Affirming sensitization meeting with Immigration Officials on the needs of Transgender persons. A two day’s workshop was held in December to sensitise Immigration Officials on Transgender issues. The meeting attended by participants from the Ministry of Home affairs, Immigration officers, Registrar general’s office, Police officers, Zimbabwe Lawyers for Human Rights and Law society of Zimbabwe deliberated on the challenges related to human rights violations faced by the Transgender community and the right to identity and self-determination. The meeting deliberated on strategies for addressing and/or mitigating the crisis situations as it relates to Immigration; propose follow up and joint course of action by the Ministry of Home Affairs/Immigration department, NAC, Civil Society Organisations and the transgender community, for effective integration of transgender issues in national strategic plans (NSPs) and other relevant policy; Create space where transgender community can articulate their concerns, demand for change and develop alliances that further their well-being; Advocate for their human rights to legal gender recognition through sensitizing and engaging the Ministry of Home Affairs, Immigration Office, Registrar General’s office and law enforcement agents; facilitate a conducive environment for the transgender community through exchange of information and integrating trans inclusive services within the Ministry of Home Affairs, immigration and Registrar General’s offices; Deconstruct barriers between the transgender community and the Immigration Office, Registrar General’s office, Ministry of Home Affairs and law enforcement agents. The expected outcome of the meeting was the recognition for improved access to services such as legal gender recognition and transgender persons inclusion by the Immigration Office, Ministry of Home Affairs, Police and even the Registrar General’s office; improved understanding of the needs and existence of Transgender communities; and reduction in human rights violations targeted at transgender persons within government departments. In Madagascar the HIV Commission is in the process of reviewing the HIV Law 2005 -040 and amendment of the decree and rules of procedure. To ensure that the law is grounded on human rights principles and protective of key populations and vulnerable communities. Some of the proposal focus on HIV testing of children under 18 years of age; criminalization of voluntary transmission; and introduction of condoms in prisons etc. all these issues being critical for access to SRH/ HIV services for key populations and vulnerable groups. A sensitization meeting was held for some of the Commissioners on the LEA findings and recommendations, the position recommended by the Global Commission on HIV and the Law (GCHL). It was agreed that there would be a need to review the proposed law prior to being tabled in the first Parliamentary seating in 2020.
f. Conduct Regional Meeting of the National Steering Committees. The 3rd regional meeting of the Linking Policy to Programming project’s National Steering Committee (NSC)’s from the 5 project countries was held in July 2019. The meeting aimed at providing the NSCs with an opportunity to reflect, review and update on the LPP interventions in their countries such as the implementation of the Legal Environment Assessment (LEA) and its recommendation, effectiveness of the management structure at national level, creating a platform for engagement with young key populations and sharing of best practices. The meeting was led by UNDP supported by the consortium members AMSHeR and HEARD. The structure of the regional meeting focused more on sharing of in country experiences on the implementation and management of the LEA processes, outcome of the LEA and how YKPs have been involved in the processes, including sharing of strategies for integration into national strategic documents. This provided an opportunity for peer review and learning from other countries. The objectives of the meeting was to review the process of undertaking the LEA in each country, identify strengths, and highlight challenges and limitations of the process; agree on strategies for the integration of LEA recommendations and the National Action Plan into national strategic plans and monitoring frameworks; identify priority areas of action in each country focusing on legal and policy issues around young key populations; and integrate lessons and findings from the baseline research and the Advocacy Working Group (AWG) activities into the implementation strategies of the LEA. Participants discussed and shared experiences with the progress of the LEAs, the research, capacity building and advocacy in each country, including the successes, challenges, lessons learned and recommendations for the respective processes as well as discussing the findings, recommendations and outcomes of the LEAs, advocacy and research. Information was shared on key developments in HIV, Tuberculosis (TB), sexual and reproductive health law and human rights affecting all persons, particularly young key populations, globally and in the region. Country teams identified priorities for action and finalized their action plans, based on the discussions, and further identified strategies for implementing priority advocacy and actions aimed at strengthening access to sexual and reproductive health and rights of YKPs in the 5 project countries. From the presentations it was evident that most countries have integrated the LPP project activities in their national management structures, such as national key population forum plans, an outfit constituted by government officials and CSO working with Key Populations, which ensures sustainability of the project initiatives. Young key populations are also part of the KP Forum which provided a platform for engagement with technical officers and policy makers. The meeting also observed that some countries have produced Key Population Implementation Plans which incorporate the LEA recommendations such as Zimbabwe and Angola. Angola is yet to adopt its KP implementation plan at national Level. There seem to be political will in all the countries to implement key population focused activities, evident by the national plans developed and National AIDS Commissions’ committing to support KP programming. However, resource allocation remains a concern, most of the KP related initiatives are funded by external donors. Countries are also more comfortable working on broader key population issues generally, than addressing young key populations specific needs, even though young key populations serves as a good entry points for working with political leaders such as Members of Parliament. There is need to strengthen dissemination of all the products produced in the project and further ensure strengthened capacity of YKPs on interpersonal skills, such as public speaking, confidence building and analytical skills to complement their advocacy skills. Lastly the meeting provided the opportunity for the countries to review and finalise the National action plans for implementing the LEA recommendations.
INTERVENTION AREA 4. RELEVANT TOOLS AND GUIDANCE ON THE HIV/SRH-RELATED NEEDS AND RIGHTS OF EACH YOUNG KEY POPULATION DEVELOPED.
a. Continue roll out of YKP score card and advocacy guide to countries:
An SRH Score Card was developed in 2017, a framework designed by Accountability International for monitoring access to SRH services by key population. It was envisaged that the scorecard would be rolled out to all project countries and young key populations would be involved as data collectors. Only one report has been produced in Zimbabwe following the finalization of the scorecard. When the project was conceptualized it assumed that the SRH Scorecard was a tool developed by AMSHER, however Accountability International has the rights to the scorecard and its implementation costs not included in the project. The logistics and costs of implementing this activity have led to the delays in achieving this result in the project countries. This will be extensively reported under the AMSHeR report.
b. Develop KP Stigma Index Guideline
The SADC Regional Strategy for HIV Prevention Treatment and Care and Sexual Reproductive Health and Rights for Key Population has 4 results areas and 13 Indicators one of which is ensuring that the 16 Member States undertake the KP focused Stigma Index. The development of a KP Stigma guideline was therefore proposed to assist countries with this undertaking. Towards the end of 2018 UNAIDS in collaboration with GNP+ released a Stigma Index 2.0 which provides a comprehensive guidance (assessment tool) that is inclusive of Key populations. GNP+ is presently implementing the Stigma Index in 8 SADC countries 2 of which are the LPP project countries, Zimbabwe and Mozambique. Discussions are underway with GNP+ on how we can further collaborate in the implementation of the Sigma Index 2.0 INTERVENTION AREA 5: Assist SADC to Strengthen Regional Frameworks to Ensure they Address HIV/SRH Needs and Rights of Young Key Populations.
a. Training of YKPs on Global and Regional commitments on Human Rights and SRH and reporting processes The Engagement Scan training for young key populations from the project countries held in September 2019 (See YKP capacity building section above) incorporated this activity. YKPs were introduced to the various International and Regional protocols most of the project countries have ratified. The 9 international human rights frameworks and the preparation of the Universal Periodic Report (UPR; the respective committees responsible for each convention for accountability and reporting procedures; the opportunities for engaging in the state report processes and preparation of shadow reports. At the end of the training YKPs were able to produce mock reports to an international and regional body. These will be developed further for submission at a later stage. To build on the training, young people were further exposed to practical sessions on the work of the committees. Five YKPs from the ES training were nominated to participate in the African Commission on Human Rights in Gambia Banjul in October accompanied by the AMSHeR team. b. Support SADC Secretariat to lead and coordinate implementation of the KP strategy UNDP collaborating with UNFPA UNAIDS and UNDOC sustained the support to SADC Secretariat HIV Portfolio for the coordination and monitoring of the implementation of the KP Regional Strategy in September 2019. The 3 days coordination’s meeting attended by the NAC Directors is usually preceded by a two-day meeting attended by the member States Technical team from the NAC and the Ministry of Health. Sixty-five participants attended the meeting from the 16 countries, including KP Regional CSO, Development partners and UN agencies. Member States review progress in the implementation of the 2020 HIV prevention targets and KP Programmes; share experiences on effective programs for Key populations and identify common structural barriers in the provision of targeted services for KPs; build consensus on the National Package of HIV Prevention Services for different Key Populations in the SADC region; discuss resource allocation and the financial landscape for KP programming and issues of law and policy; identify country specific successful innovative approaches to KP programming for documentation and sharing of good practices and develop plans for scaling up programs for KP to reach Fast Track Targets. The meeting structure was presentations, discussions and consensus on issues that needed political clout or attention to be presented to the meeting of Minister often held later in the year. The meeting produced a road map for meeting the 2020 targets, and further produced several reports for submission to the next SADC Health Minister’s meeting to be held in the United Republic of Tanzania in November 2019. An annual SADC 2019-2020 HIV and AIDS progress report was produced informed by the Member States supported by the UN Agencies and SADC Secretariat which provides the overall status of programme implementation; HIV prevention score card; CSO perspectives on the HIV progress report and the score card; SADC position on sustainable financing, and progress report on implementation of the KP strategy. A guide on “Implementing Comprehensive HIV and Sexual and Reproductive Health Programmes For Key Populations in The SADC Region: A Programme Acceleration Guide was developed under finalization. The LPP project also supported the participation of young Key Populations to participate in this meeting.
c. Support SADC Secretariat to integrate monitoring of the KP Strategy in the monitoring system of the regional HIV/SRHR plan. Annually UNDP supports SADC to undertake a monitoring exercise on the implementation of the KP Regional strategy. A developed monitoring template is shared with SADC and Member state for completion. The data is then analyzed and collated into a report which is presented to MS. This is usually a validation process to what is presented by countries. This process needs to be integrated into the broader SADC monitoring processes for sustainability. d. Support acceleration of HIV Programming in the Indian Ocean countries The LPP project supported an activity that seeks to promote the prevention of HIV and reduction of new infections amongst the Indian Ocean Countries that have relevant low HIV prevalence. A meeting themed “Accelerating evidence informed sustainable HIV prevention in the Indian Ocean Islands countries to meet fast track targets” was organized by SADC in August supported by the UN mainly UNDP, UNFPA, UNAIDS and UNODC. Countries represented included Comoros, Mauritius, Madagascar and Seychelles. The meeting attended by M&E Offices, Civil Society Organisations and NAC Directors was in two-fold, capacity building of the technical officers on undertaking size estimates for key populations using data from multiple sources, identify data gaps, develop a draft epi profile structure including road map. The second meeting was attended by the Directors of the NACs and their technical teams used evidence generated from the capacity building workshop to review programme status, identify challenges related to meeting the HLM targets and develop a country roadmap. The objectives of the meeting was to take stock of progress against HLM targets on prevention; identify challenges in achieving HLM targets on prevention with specific focus on Key Populations and preparing a road map to meet the targets; develop an understanding of the issues around sustainability and draft a way forward and build capacity of countries in analyzing available data to inform programming and identify data needs for future. Due to the low prevalence in the IOC countries they seem to lag behind the rest of SADC in the implementation of HIV related programmes and HIV infections is concentrated amongst key populations. The meeting generated interest in the development of programmes that will focus on KP programmes. there is limited funding for IOC Countries to implement HIV programme with the major donors not prioritizing countries with a low burden. The countries presented minimal data on KPs which can serve as an entry point for programme development, there was general appetite in developing programmes that will target YKPs including undertaking YKP focused research. Mauritius and Seychelles will be conducting Stigma and discrimination index in 2019/2020. An opportunity for UNDP to collaborate with the respective team at UNAIDS. They IOC advised on the need to include the Reunion in such planning meetings, for shared experiences and lessons learned and they are part of the IOC.
PROGRAMME MANAGEMENTS.
a. Annual Meeting: HEARD hosted the consortium annual meeting in February 2019, which was twofold. The annual meeting was whereby the 2018 results were discussed and 2019 plan presented and agreed on. Further the meeting provided an opportunity to conduct face to face consultation meeting with consortium partners. This was the first consultation meeting followed by the questionnaire.
b. Midterm Review A Midterm review was undertaken by HEARD in accordance with the donor agreement between the month of January and June 2019. The terms of reference were developed and approved by the donor in 2018. The objectives of the MTR was to take stock of the project’s progress to date towards the realization of its overall and specific objectives against the results framework and the theory of change; to interpret the project progress, applying standard evaluation criteria and the principles of a human rights framework; to identify the successes and challenges from each of the partners and the consortium as a whole in the implementation of the project; to identify lessons learnt and current or emerging best practices in the domains of policy engagement, advocacy and accountability strategies and research with young key populations; to propose course corrections for strengthening the ability of the project to achieve its overall expected results for young key populations by the end of its term in 2020. A reference group was established represented by the three consortium members tasked with the management of the overall MTR process including review of data collection tools. Consultation was at national and reginal level. Three countries were selected for data collection Zambia, Zimbabwe and Mozambique. The report was presented and accepted by the donor in July.
c. Joint Monitoring Mission A joint donor mission was organized In Madagascar attended by the three consortium members and the regional consultant. Such meetings enable the donor to directly interact and engage with the LPP project beneficiaries or stakeholder. d. Quarterly Monitoring LPP project monitoring continue as per agreement. 6 weekly meeting were held with the consortium as appropriate and quarterly meetings were held with country offices. e. Financial management. Consortium partners continued to be supported with financial management and liquidation of funds. A mission was undertaken to AMSHER in October by the finance team. The objectives of the meeting were to assess and evaluate that organisational financial systems are in place as per agreement and adhered to. This involved assessing project supporting document; ensuring that original supporting documents of the LPP project are available and readily accessible; documents are filed based on the order of the reported FACE Forms; all original documents supporting the FACE forms are approved and complete; the original supporting documents are reconciled with the quarterly financial authorization and certification of expenditures (FACE Form), and reported expenses are consistent with the signed Responsible Party Agreement, Annual Work Plans and Budget including bank reconciliation. Additionally, a refresher training on financial reporting i.e. preparation of the FACE Form and forecasting was done. This training support is consistent with UNDP mandate of strengthening national institutions in organisational development.

1. Four National Legal Environment Assessments validation meetings held in Angola, Madagascar,Zambia and Zimbabwe and LEA Reports produced and finalised. The reports are now being edited and finalised for publication. Mozambique preliminary LEA results have been presented to stakeholder and currently being finalised for validation in the first quarter. 2. Five National Action plans developed and implemented. 3. Five Engagement Scan finalised and Action plans developed and implemented 4. One Regional meeting held with the LEA National Steering Committee 5. One Regional meeting held for the integration of YKP issues in National Curricula 6. YKP Advocacy Guide and SRH Scorecard rolled out in the five countries. 7. Community dialogues, and training held in Angola and Madagascar including establishment of Advocacy Working groups. 8. Implementation of Advocacy Plan and Capacity Assessment in Mozambique,Zambia and Zimbabwe 9. Community Capacity Building meetings and training held in Mozambique, Zambia and Zimbabwe. 10. Small grants to YKP Organisations and Groups established 11. Implementation of Advocacy Work plans 12. Integrate YKP Issues in the SADC SRH Scorecard 13. Sensitise SADC Parliamentary Forum on KP Strategy 14. Support YKPs to participate in Regional Meetings and Events 15. Finalise Baseline data on SRH and Indicators 16. Five Operational Research Reports produced in the five countries. 17. One Annual planning Meeting held

Intervention 1: LEA and National Action Planning. Four countries Angola, Madagascar, Zambia and Zimbabwe finalized their national Legal and Policy Environment Assessments (LEA), conducted national validating meetings for the LEA reports and developed draft national action plans. Five missions have been undertaken by the Regional Office team and regional consultants to provide technical support and guidance to the national validation meetings. The reports are now being reviewed and edited at regional level by the regional consultants in readiness for publishing and launching of the reports. The editing ensures reports alignment with international norms and language used is consistent with the principles of the LEA. The draft National Action Plans developed identifies key advocacy actions for the implementation of the recommendations in the LEA reports in the project countries. Its envisaged that the prioritized actions will contribute towards legal and policy reform for HIV/SRHR services for young key populations. Mozambique draft report has been produced and preliminary results have been presented to the national stakeholders for their inputs. The report is being finalized and will be validated in the first quarter of 2019. The National Steering Committee in Mozambique has been revitalized with new organisations identified and appointment process should have been finalized. The NSC has an oversight function towards achieving the implementation of the LEA and its recommendations. Intervention 2: Engagement Scans: Five engagement scans (ES) have been completed in the project countries and translated into Portuguese and French for Angola, Mozambique and Madagascar respectively. Missions have been undertaken to Zimbabwe, Madagascar and Mozambique by the Regional Service Center team to work with the members of the National Steering Committee (NSC) and the National Advocacy Group on operationalization of the engagement scan. The missions involved orienting stakeholders, on what is an engagement scan, its purpose, and how it fits into the broader project interventions, such as the legal environment assessments (LEAs), work of the advocacy working group and implementation of the national action plans; presentation of the ES as it applies to the individual countries to ensure a shared understanding on the various roles and responsibilities of civil society organisation and obtain feedback from stakeholders to further enrich the final draft. The meetings result in extensive discussions on how Civil Society Organisations can create space for engagement with policy makers, government officials and Members of Parliament and also highlight at the missed opportunities for constructive engagement on policy issues with these institutions. The ES meetings are informed by government, parliamentarians, civil society organisations and young key populations including the Members of the National Steering Committee and National Advocacy working groups (NAWG). Recognizing the complementary roles to be undertaken by the NSC and the NAWG Zimbabwe NSC recommended for the inclusion of the NAWG in the broader NSC to harmonise implementation of activities. These meetings prove to be helpful and educational to both CSO and government officials who have not been active on advocacy. All the countries have recommended for the training for KP led organisation and YKPs on the effective engagement with policy makers and the use of ES. Intervention 3a. Capacity Building: Regional Meeting National Steering Committee The Second Regional annual meeting for the National Steering Committee was held on the 7-8th August 2018 in Pretoria South Africa. The meeting was attended by 40 participants from across 5 project countries, namely Angola, Madagascar, Mozambique, Zambia and Zimbabwe. Participants were composed of NSC members from the 5 countries, Young Key Population’s Advocacy Working Group (AWG), members of the HEARD research team and UNDP. Additional participants were from UNFPA and UNESCO. The meeting focused on strengthening oversight capacity of the NSC members on meaningful engagement and participating in finalization of the LEA and Engagement Scan and identify follow-up actions (mapping progress, identifying gaps and challenges and develop workplans). It further identified opportunities for strengthening co-ordination between the various projects initiated at national level. Provided a networking platform for ongoing communication and support between UNDP and NSC members. The NSC and AWG were introduced to regional and international guidance. •The 2018 GCHL Supplementary Chapter to the 2012 report, Risks, Rights & Health, to provide guidance on new and emerging issues arising since then. •UNESCO 2015 study on school-related violence, conducted in Botswana, Lesotho, Namibia, South Africa and eSwatini, including on whether learners, educators and other school staff were perceived differently and/or were subjected to greater violence as a result of gender norms and stereotypes. Discussions also covered comprehensive sexual reproductive health education package developed by UNESCO which is inclusive of key populations. •The SADC Regional Strategy for Prevention, Treatment and Care and SRHR Among Key Populations was approved by Ministers of Health from SADC in November 2017. •The WHO Technical Briefs which provide guidance to policy-makers, donors, service-planners, service-providers and community-led organizations on how best to provide services, programmes and support for young key populations. •The Abidjan Declaration on Young Key Populations developed by young LGBTI, PLWHA, sex workers and persons who inject drugs from across Africa, at a pre-conference meeting ahead of the 19th International Conference on AIDS and STIs in Africa (ICASA) in Abidjan, 2017. The meeting recommended that the training should remain a 3 day meeting to allow for discussions and debates on key issues such as the technical briefs (WHO,UNESCO); to ensure continuity there should be consistency with participation, the team from Mozambique was new and could not follow as the meeting was a build on to 2017 training; group activities should be focused more on cross-country’ learning to allow sharing of expertise; and hosting of the meeting should be rotational within project countries. 3b. Regional Meeting on the Integration of YKP Issues in National Curricula: Further to consultations with Kenya Ethics and Legal Issues Network (KELIN) and South African Judicial Education Institute (SAJEI) who have extensive knowledge and experience in training Law enforcements officers and Judges on Health, HIV and Human Rights amongst other topics. An internal agreement has been reached that the priority for this intervention will focus on Law enforcements training Institutes. The approach for the integration of Key Populations issues, HIV, Health and Human Rights into national curricula will be in two phases. The first phase will entail undertaking a situational analysis on how KPs issues and Human rights have been integrated within the Law enforcements training Institutes or in-service training programmes; review tools, methodology adopted for such trainings; produce a discussion paper that articulates various scenarios for integrating KP issues in law enforcement training programmes; conduct a regional meeting for law enforcement training institutions and agree on a strategy and work plan for integration of KP issues. To foster project ownership and enhanced sustainability a regional consultant will be recruited to provide direct support to each country on demand basis. This is scheduled for the first quarter in 2019. 3c. International and Regional Forums: A total of 25 participants were sponsored by UNDP (15) and AMSHeR (10) to attend the International AIDS Conference Themed “Breaking Barriers, Building Bridges” held from the 22-27th July 2018, Amsterdam. The consortium led non-commercial satellite symposium themed “How do we Achieve Health Equity for Young Key Populations (YKPs) in Africa?” which was a 2-hour session held on the 23rd July 2018 with over 70-80% room capacity of 277 persons. The symposium adopted two approaches presentations from the three consortium members and panel discussions led by the project partners in government, youth, SADC and Parliament representatives who shared on practical experiences of working on policy and programming for key populations. The discussions touched on age of consent for your people in sub-Saharan Africa; policy and legislative framework as a deterrent to access to services; the diverse constitutional definitions of key populations in the region; strengthening of health service provision; improving comprehensive sexual education; strengthening SADC accountability and involvement of policy makers especially parliamentarians in leading national dialogues on issues affecting key populations to mention a few. A short video was also produced that depict the challenges experienced by Young key populations when accessing health services http://www.africa.undp.org/content/rba/en/home/presscenter/articles/2018/achieving-health-equity-for-young-key-populations-crucial-to-end.html. The consortium members also participated in a poster exhibition that focused on “Accessing Universal Health Care for all by 2030 - Improving legal and policy environments to ensure equitable access to HIV and SRHR services for Young Key Populations (YKPs) in Africa” (UNDP), Towards a healthy engagement model of stakeholders in HIV policy formulation by regional policy organs: Case study of the Report on HIV, Law and Human Rights within the African Human Rights System” (AMSHeR). At the Conference AMSHeR also supported several activities led by Young Key Populations at the youth Networking Zone whereby a platform for sharing of experiences was facilitated led by YKPs from different regions such as Africa and Eastern Europe. At the conference AMSHeR also strengthened its collaboration with other UN Agencies such as UNFPA and UNAIDS as they co-led other initiatives aimed at promoting access to sexual and reproductive health and rights for young key populations. Also participating in these youths led events was the African Commission Secretariat and HIV Committee Expert’s members as well as ARASA. Intervention 4. Roll Out of the YKP Advocacy Guide and SRH Scorecard: The YKP Advocacy Guide has been finalized following a regional stakeholder’s meeting to review and validate the guide prior to its launch and dissemination. A total of 27 participants constituting of young key populations (gay and msm, bisexual, transgender, intersex, drug injecting users, sex workers and lesbians) attended the review meeting from the five project countries including representatives from Kenya and South African based NGOs. The meeting jointly convened by AMSHeR and UNDP was held in Pretoria, South Africa. The meeting enabled young key populations to review and make inputs to the final draft YKP Advocacy guide; identify and reach consensus on prioritized advocacy issues per community and also provide practical examples that could be incorporated into the guide to further enrich it; review the language appropriateness and suggest relevant youth friendly language that could be adopted for the Advocacy guide; recommend simulations, illustrations or animations for inclusion in the guide for an increased understanding and to jointly identify a range of innovative strategies for access and dissemination, which could include an online training programme that would be easily accessed by young key populations active on various social media platforms. The Advocacy Guide for Policy Change on SRHR of Young Key Population was launched and disseminated at the youth zone - International AIDS Conference in Amsterdam, July 2018. Partnership was firmed up with Accountability International on the roll out of the HIV and SRHR Scorecard. Zimbabwe young key populations have been trained on the use of the scorecard and data collection is presently underway. Intervention 5: Integrate YKP Issues in SADC SRH Score Card / Targets: a)Monitoring Progress on agreed Regional SADC Commitments. The UN has adopted a collaborative approach towards strengthening the capacity of SADC on the integration of Key populations in its strategic frameworks as well as promoting investments in prevention interventions for the reduction of new HIV infections in the region. Pursuant to the adoption of the Regional Strategy for HIV prevention and Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights in the SADC Region, establishment of 2020 prevention targets and score card in 2017 through the support of the UN agencies (UNDP, UNFPA and UNAIDS). Four regional meetings have been supported in 2018. A regional meeting was supported in April to review progress on the implementation of the SADC regional strategy for HIV prevention and SRHR for key populations; review progress made against the road map adopted by Member States in the previous SADC meeting held in 2017; discuss the implementation and roll out of the SADC Key Population Strategy and share new evidence around prevention emerging from EHPSA and other regional and/or multi country research. The meeting was attended by 63 participants from 14 SADC counties, comprised of NAC Directors; Ministry of Health Head of HIV programs; HIV Prevention Focal persons in NAC/MOH; SADC Secretariat; It was noted that progress towards increasing access to services for KPs was varied amongst countries and common interventions focused on the integration of KP issues in NSPs, conducting legal environment assessments and development of service provision packages for key populations. Major gaps still exists in implementing several areas of the strategy such as strengthening local resource mobilization for KP interventions which remain highly dependent on external resources particularly GFATM and PEPFAR; developing and rolling out differentiated service packages for different KP groups, data collection and analyses, understanding and addressing the specific challenges of young key populations, ensuring effectiveness of mechanisms to protect KPs from violence, stigma and discrimination. The meeting recommended clear plans for effective implementation of the SADC KP regional strategy and establishment of accountability mechanisms at national level; provision of technical support to SADC countries for the implementation of the Strategy; strengthen SADC mechanisms and capacity for direct technical support including strategies for enforcement of Ministerial decisions; UNDP to provide technical support for the collation of baseline indicators for the KP Strategy M&E framework. A follow up meeting was held in October 2018 in Namibia whereby the SADC Secretariat presented to Member states, reports to be tabled to the Ministers meeting and further agree on pressing emerging issues that needed to be addressed by Ministers. The meeting attended by NAC Directors reviewed the HIV and SRH documents to be submitted for Ministerial Approval including Scorecard on HIV Prevention; SADC HIV epidemic Report; Progress report on the implementation of the Global Coalition 10-point action; Progress update on AGYW initiatives; Draft SADC SRH Strategy; Draft SADC Scorecard for SRH; Implementation Progress Reports for Ministerial Decisions. The meeting further discussed the achievements and lessons of the implementation of the HIV Fund Projects Round 2 and progress made in the funding of the HIV Cross Border Wellness Clinics under the SADC HIV and AIDS Fund; and review the Draft of the End Term Evaluation of the SIDA Support 2010-2016.
b. Sensitization of SADC Parliamentarians on the Regional Score Card and SADC Strategy: UNDP and UNFPA partnered with SADC Parliamentary Forum (SADC PF) to develop “Minimum Standards for strengthening the role of Parliamentarians for removing barriers for HIV prevention and SRHR programming for Key Populations in the SADC region. This follows the adoption of the SADC Regional Strategy for HIV and AIDS Prevention, Treatment and Care and Sexual and Reproductive Health. A regional meeting held in November 2018 in Maputo reviewed the Minimum Standards for Parliamentarians for the Protection of Key Populations in the SADC Region and creation of an enabling policy and legal environment. This meeting attended by Parliamentarians followed a regional symposium held on the same in August 2018 where amendments were proposed, and indicators discussed including guidance for domestication of the Minimum Standards, and monitoring mechanisms for tracking progress towards full implementation of the Standards. The Minimum standards were approved and adopted by Parliamentarians in November 2018. c. Support Participation of YKPs in Regional Events: Participating of young key populations in strategic policy meetings is vital for their capacity building. A strategic decision was undertaken and supported by SADC Secretariat that young people participate in most of the open SADC Technical meetings. In 2018 five young people from the project countries participated in the SADC meeting held in April 2018. The aim was to provide a platform for young key populations to interact and share their experiences with SADC members. YKPs were couched and mentored on framing their discussions and questions to Member States and encouraged to contribute and share their experiences. Out of the 25 participants that attended 16 young key populations were supported to participate in various events held at the International AIDS Conference in Amsterdam in July. d.
