Regional Capacity Building of Young Key Populations on SRHR – Botswana Gaborone: AMSHeR Regional office partnered with Lesbians Gays and Bisexuals of Botswana (LEGABIBO) to host the second annual pre-conference Learning and Leadership institute a strategy aimed at empowering young people on a range of issues that can impact on policy reform and social change such as advocacy and movement building. The pre-conference preceded the Pan-African bi-annual conference theme; ‘Empowering LGBTI Youth: Uniting for an Inclusive Future ‘convened by the International Lesbian and Gay Association (ILGA) that took place from 1-5 June 2018 in Gaborone Botswana. The main conference had over 200 participants in attendance from all continents. The pre-conference meeting was attended by 25 young advocates, of which 13 were from the 5 project countries funded by the LPP project. The objectives of the learning and training institute were to enhance capacity of YKPs in advocacy skills for removal of discriminatory and punitive laws; enlighten participants on the review process for Penal Codes which criminalize same sex relationships; explore strategies for enforcement of protective laws and strengthen the rights of citizens including women, girls and the wide range of key populations; explore ways of strengthening mechanisms to implement and enforce laws that address high level of sexual and gender-based violence; explore strategies for the integration of KP/YKP indicators in National Strategic Plans; advance the conversation on laws related to minimum age of consent for enhanced access to sexual and reproductive health services; discuss laws and policies that relate to people in prison and related barriers to access services; and identify advocacy tips related to strengthening service provision policies, understanding complaints procedures and remedial mechanisms. The training explored various concepts relevant for YKPs such as understanding concepts on binaries, sexuality, gender and human right, Health and Wellness in queer lives, policy and advocacy, narrowing into the challenges of being a young advocate. Further YKPs were introduced to Regional and International instruments aimed at protecting individual’s rights. A special guest from the United Nations Independent expert on Sexual Orientation and Gender Identity was also invited to orient YKPs on the various UN mandate. The approach adopted was participatory with a lot of group work and plenary, an online #PAICon2018 social media twitter page was established to engage and share discussions with other YKPs. Facilitation of the meetings were led by YKPs further creating a youth friendly environment in the meeting. Intervention 6: Capacity Strengthening for YKP on Policy Engagement; HIV/SRH rights and Access to justice Capacity building of the KP Community continued in Madagascar using the AMSHeR Advocacy Curriculum. This training was re-phased from 2017 to 2018 due to some institutional challenges in Madagascar. The facilitators who are regional based are guided by the advocacy curriculum developed by AMSHeR with a clear methodology to ensure consistency with the training outputs. The workshop was attended by 30 representatives from YKP organizations; technical staff of national and provincial agencies responsible for HIV and KP programming and most exposed to risk populations YKP MER and CBOs working in HIV and key populations; Key personnel of health and HIV policy-making institutions; National representatives of UNDP and other representations of technical partners from NGOs working on HIV. The young key populations community dialogue meeting attended by 40 young people preceded by the training on Advocacy, generated and prioritized a list of issues affecting YKPs. The issues prioritized were presented to the workshop participants who further came up with strategies for engaging policy makers on the issues (AWG Action Plan). b. Capacity assessment and MoU signing with ASSOFRAMA May 2018 AMSHeR team conducted a capacity assessment of the MSM & Transgender led organization – affiliate partner to the project: Association for Fraternity in Madagascar (ASSOFRAMA). The Organizational Capacity Assessment tool (OCAT) developed and used by AMSHeR for all its affiliates was used to gather data on the capacity needs of the organisation. It explores a broad range of performance parameters and comprises 12 components, each of which contain several sub-components. The sub-components drill down into various aspects of the organisation and its systems (e.g. vision and mission; strategic plan; and board composition under the Leadership and Governance component). Each sub-component is clearly defined with a score that range from 1-5. The scores are then aggregated to provide the overall rating of the organisation. A report on the status of the organization is automatically generated and capacity development actions are agreed between the AMSHeR team of evaluators and the leadership of the organization. A Memorandum of Understanding has been signed between AMSHeR and ASSOFRAMA the partner organisation that will now implement the YKP project in Madagascar. A capacity development support plan for institutional development has been agreed upon. Iris in Angola has also been supported to officially register its organisation. The registration will enhance its capacity to operate more efficiently, additional staff is also being engaged to support with Implementation. Intervention 7: Mechanisms for Community Monitoring. A multi-stakeholder Advocacy Working Group (AWG) was established in Madagascar and Angola respectively completing the establishment of five Advocacy Working Groups in all the project countries. The membership in both countries was drawn from representatives of YKPs: Ministry of Health, Ministry of Youth, Ministry of Education, National AIDS Commission, PSI, and Civil Society Organisation as well as International NGOs working with Key populations. The AWG convenes its own meetings and the chair and co-chair are elected in the first meeting held, they further agree on subsequent meeting structure. Further the AWG members were tasked with the responsibility of developing a result framework for the advocacy priorities identified as well as speeding up the implementation. The participants attending the advocacy training committed to contribute to the work of the AWG as per need. The Advocacy plans will be supported through the small grant budget initiative. Angola AWG has prioritized - Ending sexual violence among key populations, self-stigma and fear of exposure due to health professionals and prison officials' attitude; and Integration of key populations issues into the sexual and reproductive health programmes in Angola. Madagascar priorities include – Advocating for the development and implementation of a strategy to disseminate Law No. 2005/040 (article 50) in schools and law enforcement agencies by Dec. 2019. Secondly advocate for the establishment of an outreach mechanism for the law on self-inflicted assault and moral sequestration of the public and law enforcement officers by Dec. 2019 Zambia has had challenges with the implementation of its activities outlined in the Advocacy Working Plan due to the increasing hostile environment targeting key populations organisation by the Government. Transbantu, the AMSHeR affiliate organisational account was suspended, which halted all activities. A hostile media report in one newspaper led to the organisation taking the necessary precautions to protect its community resulting in slowed down implementation of the set activities. UNDP and TransBantu have met to revise the workplan and agree on the next steps. Implementation of the Advocacy plan in Zimbabwe was also slowed down by the elections and its aftermath. In-country activities were then differed to December while monitoring the situation and to avoid any manipulation. Logistic and programmatic preparations for the in-country capacity strengthening for young key populations is underway. Intervention 8: Baseline Survey: In Angola the team finalized the literature review report for Angola. The necessary preparations for elite interviews with key stakeholders and travel were made to enable the baseline field component to proceed in the next quarter. Following the analysis of the baseline data, a research protocol will be developed and submitted to the appropriate ethics committee by the end of the first/beginning of the second quarter, 2019. Intervention 9 Operational Research Zimbabwe: Data collection tools were developed, and research training provided, during a country visit by the HEARD researcher. Data collection for the operational research commenced in quarter 4. In Mozambique Data collection tools and research guidance documents were developed. The country baseline report was submitted to the bio-medical ethics committee as part of the application to renew the research approval for another year. A few small amendments were made to the original protocol to align with the foci of the operational research. These changes were approved by the committee and an extension for the research was granted for the coming year. Data collection for the operational research commenced in quarter 4. In Zambia Data collection tools were developed and research assistants recruited for the data collection phase of the operational research, during a country visit by the HEARD researcher which coincided with the project monitoring mission of the project officer from the RNE, Maputo. In Madagascar Data collection tools were developed and piloted, while research assistants were recruited and trained for deployment to the various study sites. Data collection for the operational research commenced in quarter 4. Data collection commenced in quarter 4. Prepare research training materials and programme for in-country partners HEARD convened a regional meeting for their research partners from the project countries. The meeting served a three-fold purpose; 1) to hold an academic exchange on the baseline findings; 2) to discuss and refine the research methodologies and foci for the next phase research in each country; and 3) to provide training on specific subject areas to the partners. The training included the following areas: • applying the conceptual framework of the overall research to the country studies • ethical challenges of doing research with young key population groups • researching sexual orientation and gender identity in challenging contexts • methodological issues for conducting research with young key populations • applying semi-structured and biographical narrative interview techniques • gathering economic data on out of pocket expenses for SRH services in YKP
In addition to the organisation of this regional-level training, HEARD core team members also facilitated country-level trainings during this quarter and continuous mentorship will be provided to strengthen research partners’ capacities - online and during country visits – during the implementation of the operational research. Intervention 10 Development of HIV/ SRH Indicators HEARD facilitated a one-day workshop on indicator development with the consortium partners in Durban. Participatory methods were used to guide group sessions during the day and agreements on the way forward included the organisation of a consultation with YKPs on (the purpose of) indicators during the RNE project monitoring mission to Zambia. The HEARD core team member leading the research in Zambia attended this consultation. Project Coordination and Management: Monthly project update scheduled monitoring calls to assess progress at national level continue to be held within the various teams, this provides an opportunity to deal with any challenges immediately as they arise. Coordination calls between the Consortium members are held every six weeks to update each other on the progress and upcoming activities. The three consortium partners also contribute to the review of various documents and concept notes related to various project activities. A Joint mission planned for 2018 in Zimbabwe has been differed to 2019. There were several challenges experienced regarding this mission resulting on postponement of the joint mission. Zimbabwe had its national presidential elections in July 2018 which left the country unstable for two months thereafter. Additionally, it had been envisaged that all the country reports, baselines and Legal environment assessment would be complete by then, documents critical to the development of a social change Agenda for Zimbabwe that will be targeted by the project. The joint mission will now take place later in the first quarter of 2019.

1. Technical support provided for the implementation of the LEA Recommendation in the five countries 2. Young Key Populations engagement facilitated with Parliamentarians and LEA integrated in National Action Plans 3. Fourth National Steering committee conducted 4. Young Key Populations trained on the application of the Civil Society Engagement Scan in Health and Policy 5. Young Key Populations capacity strengthened in five countries ( convene one joint caucus for all YKPs and per community Group) 6. Regional Meeting on Advocacy for YKPs and support YKP participation at regional Level. 7. Conduct SADC Regional KP Strategy implementation progress review 8. Collaborate with UNFPA, UNAIDS and support SADC NAC Directors MS Annual meeting 9. Finalize Operational Research in all project countries 10. Develop country Specific Scientific publication and research briefs 11 Perform cross country data analyses 12. Hold two core research team and one annual regional research meeting 13. Produce change stories based on project interventions 14. Develop cost effective analysis of human rights and HIV programming 15. Conduct one Donor monitoring meeting.
